header.title: gb_sets

description.p: An implementation of ordered sets using Prof. Arne Andersson's General Balanced Trees. This can be much more efficient than using ordered lists, for larger sets, but depends on the application.

section.title: Complexity note
section.p: The complexity on set operations is bounded by either O(|S|) or O(|T| * log(|S|)), where S is the largest given set, depending on which is fastest for any particular function call. For operating on sets of almost equal size, this implementation is about 3 times slower than using ordered-list sets directly. For sets of very different sizes, however, this solution can be arbitrarily much faster; in practical cases, often between 10 and 100 times. This implementation is particularly suited for accumulating elements a few at a time, building up a large set (more than 100-200 elements), and repeatedly testing for membership in the current set.
As with normal tree structures, lookup (membership testing), insertion and deletion have logarithmic complexity.

section.title: Compatibility
section.p: All of the following functions in this module also exist and do the same thing in the sets and ordsets modules. That is, by only changing the module name for each call, you can try out different set representations.

func.name: add(Element, Set1) -> Set2
add_element(Element, Set1) -> Set2
func.fsummary: Add a (possibly existing) element to a gb_set

desc.p: Returns a new gb_set formed from Set1 with Element inserted. If Element is already an element in Set1, nothing is changed.

func.name: balance(Set1) -> Set2
func.fsummary: Rebalance tree representation of a gb_set

desc.p: Rebalances the tree representation of Set1. Note that this is rarely necessary, but may be motivated when a large number of elements have been deleted from the tree without further insertions. Rebalancing could then be forced in order to minimise lookup times, since deletion only does not rebalance the tree.

func.name: delete(Element, Set1) -> Set2
func.fsummary: Remove an element from a gb_set

desc.p: Returns a new gb_set formed from Set1 with Element removed. Assumes that Element is present in Set1.

func.name: delete_any(Element, Set1) -> Set2
del_element(Element, Set1) -> Set2
func.fsummary: Remove a (possibly non-existing) element from a gb_set

desc.p: Returns a new gb_set formed from Set1 with Element removed. If Element is not an element in Set1, nothing is changed.

func.name: difference(Set1, Set2) -> Set3
subtract(Set1, Set2) -> Set3
func.fsummary: Return the difference of two gb_sets

desc.p: Returns only the elements of Set1 which are not also elements of Set2.

func.name: empty() -> Set
new() -> Set
func.fsummary: Return an empty gb_set

desc.p: Returns a new empty gb_set.

func.name: filter(Pred, Set1) -> Set2
func.fsummary: Filter gb_set elements

desc.p: Filters elements in Set1 using predicate function Pred.

func.name: fold(Function, Acc0, Set) -> Acc1
func.fsummary: Fold over gb_set elements

desc.p: Folds Function over every element in Set returning the final value of the accumulator.

func.name: from_list(List) -> Set
func.fsummary: Convert a list into a gb_set

desc.p: Returns a gb_set of the elements in List, where List may be unordered and contain duplicates.

func.name: from_ordset(List) -> Set
func.fsummary: Make a gb_set from an ordset list

desc.p: Turns an ordered-set list List into a gb_set. The list must not contain duplicates.

func.name: insert(Element, Set1) -> Set2
func.fsummary: Add a new element to a gb_set

desc.p: Returns a new gb_set formed from Set1 with Element inserted. Assumes that Element is not present in Set1.

func.name: intersection(Set1, Set2) -> Set3
func.fsummary: Return the intersection of two gb_sets

desc.p: Returns the intersection of Set1 and Set2.

func.name: intersection(SetList) -> Set
func.fsummary: Return the intersection of a list of gb_sets

desc.p: Returns the intersection of the non-empty list of gb_sets.

func.name: is_empty(Set) -> bool()
func.fsummary: Test for empty gb_set

desc.p: Returns true if Set is an empty set, and false otherwise.

func.name: is_member(Element, Set) -> bool()
is_element(Element, Set) -> bool()
func.fsummary: Test for membership of a gb_set

desc.p: Returns true if Element is an element of Set, otherwise false.

func.name: is_set(Set) -> bool()
func.fsummary: Test for a gb_set

desc.p: Returns true if Set appears to be a gb_set, otherwise false.

func.name: is_subset(Set1, Set2) -> bool()
func.fsummary: Test for subset

desc.p: Returns true when every element of Set1 is also a member of Set2, otherwise false.

func.name: iterator(Set) -> Iter
func.fsummary: Return an iterator for a gb_set

desc.p: Returns an iterator that can be used for traversing the entries of Set; see next/1. The implementation of this is very efficient; traversing the whole set using next/1 is only slightly slower than getting the list of all elements using to_list/1 and traversing that. The main advantage of the iterator approach is that it does not require the complete list of all elements to be built in memory at one time.

func.name: largest(Set) -> term()
func.fsummary: Return largest element

desc.p: Returns the largest element in Set. Assumes that Set is nonempty.

func.name: next(Iter1) -> {Element, Iter2 | none}
func.fsummary: Traverse a gb_set with an iterator

desc.p: Returns {Element, Iter2} where Element is the smallest element referred to by the iterator Iter1, and Iter2 is the new iterator to be used for traversing the remaining elements, or the atom none if no elements remain.

func.name: singleton(Element) -> gb_set()
func.fsummary: Return a gb_set with one element

desc.p: Returns a gb_set containing only the element Element.

func.name: size(Set) -> int()
func.fsummary: Return the number of elements in a gb_set

desc.p: Returns the number of elements in Set.

func.name: smallest(Set) -> term()
func.fsummary: Return smallest element

desc.p: Returns the smallest element in Set. Assumes that Set is nonempty.

func.name: take_largest(Set1) -> {Element, Set2}
func.fsummary: Extract largest element

desc.p: Returns {Element, Set2}, where Element is the largest element in Set1, and Set2 is this set with Element deleted. Assumes that Set1 is nonempty.

func.name: take_smallest(Set1) -> {Element, Set2}
func.fsummary: Extract smallest element

desc.p: Returns {Element, Set2}, where Element is the smallest element in Set1, and Set2 is this set with Element deleted. Assumes that Set1 is nonempty.

func.name: to_list(Set) -> List
func.fsummary: Convert a gb_set into a list

desc.p: Returns the elements of Set as a list.

func.name: union(Set1, Set2) -> Set3
func.fsummary: Return the union of two gb_sets

desc.p: Returns the merged (union) gb_set of Set1 and Set2.

func.name: union(SetList) -> Set
func.fsummary: Return the union of a list of gb_sets

desc.p: Returns the merged (union) gb_set of the list of gb_sets.
